CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 5-13 Careful combinations of donor and acceptor units have yielded low band polymers with a band gap of 1.3 - 1.7 eV , which lead to high PCEs exceeding 7% . 14-17 A variety of good donor moieties , including oligothiophenes , 18-23 carbazole , 24 benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene , 25-27 and dithienosilole , 14,28 have been demonstrated as useful for low band gap polymers ; good acceptor moieties including thieno- [3,4-b]thiophenes substituted with electron - withdrawing groups , 29-31 N-alkylthieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione , 25,28 benzothiadiazole , 24,32 and 2,5-bis(2-alkyl)pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-(2H,5H)-dione 33-36 have been developed. However , good acceptor moieties enabling polymers to absorb wavelengths over 800 nm remain still rare though acceptor moieties strongly affected to produce a narrow band gap. 37-40 In search of new acceptor moieties , we designed an interesting structure of N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]-pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ). The DTPD is a structural combination of thieno [3,4-b]thiophene and N-alkylpyrrole-2,5-dione. The thieno [3,4-b]thiophene is a particularly suitable structure to promote quinoid structures in conjugated polymers. 41-44 However , simple incorporation of the thieno- [3,4-b]thiophene units might increase the highest occupied molecular orbital ( HOMO ) level of polymers , which causes a significant loss of open - circuit voltages in PSCs. 42 Thus , it is desirable to attach electron - withdrawing groups such as ketone or ester groups and fluorine atoms. 12,15,30 Here we glued the Nalkylpyrrole-2,5-dione , a strong electron - withdrawing unit , 45 to the thieno [3,4-b]thiophene to bring down the HOMO level. Our DFT calculations , indeed , suggested that the DTPD would be a strong electron - withdrawing acceptor moiety ( Figure S1 ). 26,45 Therefore , each fractional unit in the DTPD may exert a synergetic effect to permit strong donor - acceptor electronic delocalization by the quinoid structure and to locate HOMO and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( LUMO ) levels of resulting low band gap polymers in a deep state when the DTPD is copolymerized with an appropriate donor moiety. Despite these promising features , to the best of our knowledge , the DTPD moiety has never been utilized to synthesize low band gap polymers for PSCs. Herein , we report synthesis and characterization of two polymers , POBDTPD and PEBDTPD , that consist of DTPD and BDT moieties substituted with octyloxy or 2-ethylhexyloxy g r o u p s , r e s p e c t i v e l y . P O B D T P D : P C 7^0 B M a n d PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blends utilized light absorption up to 900 nm in the generation of photocurrents and showed optimal morphology and efficient exciton separation , yielding PCEs exceeding 5% . This work demonstrates that the newly designed DTPD moiety is a promising building block for high performance PSCs . The thermal properties of the polymers were examined by differential scanning calorimetry ( DSC ) and thermogravimetric analysis ( TGA ). In the DSC curve , neither polymer displayed a transition up to 300 °C ( Figure S2a,b ).

Let's think step by step.

1. oligothiophenes
2. carbazole
3. benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene
4. dithienosilole
5. thieno-[3,4-b]thiophenes
6. N-alkylthieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione
7. benzothiadiazole
8. 2,5-bis(2-alkyl)pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-(2H,5H)-dione
9. N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]-pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD)
10. thieno [3,4-b]thiophene units
11. N-alkylpyrrole-2,5-dione
12. ketone or ester groups
13. fluorine atoms
14. POBDTPD
15. PEBDTPD
16. BDT moieties
17. octyloxy or 2-ethylhexyloxy groups.

These are the entities in the paragraph that can be identified as "Material Name" entities, as they refer to specific chemical compounds or structures.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

9. N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]-pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD)
10. POBDTPD
11. PEBDTPD

These are the entities in the paragraph that clearly refer to Material Names. Paragraph: 5-13 Careful combinations of donor and acceptor units have yielded low band polymers with a band gap of 1.3 - 1.7 eV , which lead to high PCEs exceeding 7% . 14-17 A variety of good donor moieties , including oligothiophenes , 18-23 carbazole , 24 benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene , 25-27 and dithienosilole , 14,28 have been demonstrated as useful for low band gap polymers ; good acceptor moieties including thieno- [3,4-b]thiophenes substituted with electron - withdrawing groups , 29-31 N-alkylthieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione , 25,28 benzothiadiazole , 24,32 and 2,5-bis(2-alkyl)pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-(2H,5H)-dione 33-36 have been developed. However , good acceptor moieties enabling polymers to absorb wavelengths over 800 nm remain still rare though acceptor moieties strongly affected to produce a narrow band gap. 37-40 In search of new acceptor moieties , we designed an interesting structure of N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]-pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ). The DTPD is a structural combination of thieno [3,4-b]thiophene and N-alkylpyrrole-2,5-dione. The thieno [3,4-b]thiophene is a particularly suitable structure to promote quinoid structures in conjugated polymers. 41-44 However , simple incorporation of the thieno- [3,4-b]thiophene units might increase the highest occupied molecular orbital ( HOMO ) level of polymers , which causes a significant loss of open - circuit voltages in PSCs. 42 Thus , it is desirable to attach electron - withdrawing groups such as ketone or ester groups and fluorine atoms. 12,15,30 Here we glued the Nalkylpyrrole-2,5-dione , a strong electron - withdrawing unit , 45 to the thieno [3,4-b]thiophene to bring down the HOMO level. Our DFT calculations , indeed , suggested that the DTPD would be a strong electron - withdrawing acceptor moiety ( Figure S1 ). 26,45 Therefore , each fractional unit in the DTPD may exert a synergetic effect to permit strong donor - acceptor electronic delocalization by the quinoid structure and to locate HOMO and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( LUMO ) levels of resulting low band gap polymers in a deep state when the DTPD is copolymerized with an appropriate donor moiety. Despite these promising features , to the best of our knowledge , the DTPD moiety has never been utilized to synthesize low band gap polymers for PSCs. Herein , we report synthesis and characterization of two polymers , POBDTPD and PEBDTPD , that consist of DTPD and BDT moieties substituted with octyloxy or 2-ethylhexyloxy g r o u p s , r e s p e c t i v e l y . P O B D T P D : P C 7^0 B M a n d PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blends utilized light absorption up to 900 nm in the generation of photocurrents and showed optimal morphology and efficient exciton separation , yielding PCEs exceeding 5% . This work demonstrates that the newly designed DTPD moiety is a promising building block for high performance PSCs . The thermal properties of the polymers were examined by differential scanning calorimetry ( DSC ) and thermogravimetric analysis ( TGA ). In the DSC curve , neither polymer displayed a transition up to 300 °C ( Figure S2a,b ).

Let's think step by step.

1. donor units: oligothiophenes, carbazole, benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene, dithienosilole
2. acceptor moieties: thieno-[3,4-b]thiophenes substituted with electron-withdrawing groups, N-alkylthieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione, benzothiadiazole, 2,5-bis(2-alkyl)pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-(2H,5H)-dione
3. N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]-pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD)
4. thieno [3,4-b]thiophene unit in DTPD
5. N-alkylpyrrole-2,5-dione unit in DTPD
6. HOMO level of polymers
7. open-circuit voltages in PSCs
8. ketone or ester groups and fluorine atoms (electron-withdrawing groups)
9. BDT moieties in POBDTPD and PEBDTPD
10. octyloxy and 2-ethylhexyloxy groups in POBDTPD and PEBDTPD, respectively.

These are the property names mentioned in the paragraph. Some of them are materials (donor units, acceptor moieties, and the newly designed DTPD moiety), while others are properties of those materials (band gap, PCEs, HOMO level, LUMO level, thermal properties, etc.).
